qas.question: What industry depended on the port of Charleston?
Where was  fresh food sold daily in Charleston in 1840?
What year did the legal importation of slaves end?
The region where cotton plantations were developed was known as what?
In what era did one million slaves get trade throughout the South?
What industry never depended on the port of Charleston?
Where was fresh food sold daily in Charleston in 1804?
What year did the legal importation of slaves start?
The region where cotton plantations weren't developed was known as what?
In what era did two million slaves get trade throughout the South?

context: By 1840, <a1_0><b6_0>the Market Hall and Sheds<b6_0/><a1_0/>, where fresh meat and produce were brought daily, became a hub of commercial activity. <a0_0><b5_0>The slave trade<b5_0/><a0_0/> also depended on the port of Charleston, where ships could be unloaded and the slaves bought and sold. The legal importation of African slaves had ended in <a2_0><b7_0>1808<b7_0/><a2_0/>, although smuggling was significant. However, the domestic trade was booming. More than one million slaves were transported from the Upper South to the Deep South <a4_0><b9_0>in the antebellum years<b9_0/><a4_0/>, as cotton plantations were widely developed through what became known as the <a3_0><b8_0>Black Belt<b8_0/><a3_0/>. Many slaves were transported in the coastwise slave trade, with slave ships stopping at ports such as Charleston.
